title: Synthetic Recap
body:
In a defensive battle befitting the era, the Cleveland Cavaliers grinded out an 82-75 victory over the Detroit Pistons. But this game, lost in the annals of a low-scoring affair, belongs to one man and one man alone: Terrell Brandon.

On a night where points were a premium, Brandon authored a masterpiece, pouring in a game-high 41 points. While the final score suggests a collective effort, this was a one-man offensive clinic against a suffocating Pistons defense. Brandon didn't just score; he was the Cavaliers' offense, carrying the load with a stunning combination of precision and volume. His performance was a beacon of individual brilliance in a game otherwise defined by missed shots and physical play.

The Pistons, led by Grant Hill's 21 points, stayed within striking distance through sheer tenacity. Yet, every time Detroit threatened to close the gap, Brandon had an answer. A pull-up jumper here, a drive to the basket there—his scoring barrage was relentless and ultimately insurmountable.

The rest of the box score reads like a footnote to Brandon's historic night. No other Cavalier reached double figures, making his 41 points an even more profound testament to his singular role. He wasn't just the best player on the floor; he *was* the floor for Cleveland.

In the end, the final score is a mere formality. The true story of this night is etched next to Terrell Brandon's name: 41 points, a towering achievement in a rock fight, and a performance for the ages that single-handedly secured a road victory for the Cavaliers.
